item.title: Obituary: Sega co-founder David Rosen has passed away at age 95
item.content:encoded:
Image via RePlay Magazine

A key early figure in the founding of video game history has passed away. On January 2, the spokesperson of Sega co-founder David Rosen informed RePlay Magazine that the former business executive and US Air Force pilot had passed away in his home in Los Angeles, CA on December 25, 2025. He was 95 years old.

Though today recognized as a leading Japanese game developer and publisher, Rosen was one of several Americans behind the slot machine and coin-op arcade companies that evolved into the company known as Sega Enterprise ltd. Rosen founded Rosen Enterprises. in 1954, first specializing in selling Japanese art and and photo booths before pivoting to the import and export of coin-operated "amusement machines."

In 1965 Rosen Enterprises merged with Nihon Goraku Bussan, a company formed by Martin Bromley, Irving Bromberg and James Humpert to inherit the assets of their prior firm Service Games (the first two letters of each word being the origin of "Sega"). Rosen became CEO of the new venture, laying the groundwork for one of today's most enduring game development firms.

Rosen helped steer Sega through acquisitions and industry shifts

Experts like Sega Mega Drive Collected Works author Keith Stuart have said Rosen was skilled at identifying and recruiting business visionaries with an eye for the future of game development. 

Related:Unity signs 'multi-title development partnership' with 2K Games

Under his watch Sega expanded as a manufacturer and distributor of arcade games, eventually being bought by Paramount Pictures parent company Gulf+Western Industries. After Gulf+Western sold Sega to Bally Manufacturing in 1982, he joined Sega executives Hayao Nakayama and  Isao Okawa to put together a buyout group that made Sega an independent company once again. 

He became chairman of Sega of America, the company's North American division, stepping down from the role in 1993 but remaining a director of Sega Japan until his retirement in 1996.

item.title: Final Fantasy Tactics - The Ivalice Chronicles sells 1 million units
item.content:encoded:
Diego Argüello, Contributing Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

January 6, 2026

1 Min Read

Newsbrief: Final Fantasy Tactics - The Ivalice Chronicles has surpassed 1 million sales.

As announced yesterday by the Final Fantasy account on social media, the milestone was met around three months after the game's launch on September 30.

The Ivalice Chronicles is a remastered rendition of Final Fantasy Tactics, which features voiced dialogue, graphic enhancements, and an array of gameplay tweaks.

While Square Enix didn't include a statement alongside the announcement, Kazutoyo Maehiro, director of the project, told Game Developer in September that if the remaster did well, it would show the business viability of the tactics genre.

"That could potentially open doors for things like Final Fantasy Advanced getting the same treatment, or sequels or new titles," Maehiro said at the time.

About the Author

Contributing Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

Diego Nicolás Argüello is a freelance journalist and critic from Argentina. Video games helped him to learn English, so now he covers them for places like The New York Times, NPR, Rolling Stone, and more. He also runs Into the Spine, a site dedicated to fostering and supporting new writers, and co-hosted Turnabout Breakdown, a podcast about the Ace Attorney series. He’s most likely playing a rhythm game as you read this.

item.title: Data suggests your game should cost between $20 and $40
item.content:encoded:
Illustration by Okw via Adobe Stock

Game analytics firm Gamesight has a new batch of data for game marketing professionals out this week, with some key metrics to help you make decisions about marketing your next game.

The report analyzes data from Gamesight platform users, drawing conclusions about the best methods for attracting, retaining, and capturing player interest. One major data point: the sweet spot for selling your game might be between $20 and $40.

Gamesight concluded this by analyzing "hours to convert" for games in different genres and at different price points. "Hours to convert" represents the average amount of time between when a player learns about a game to the moment they purchase it. The report suggests that if your premium game is priced between $20 and $40, players will take about 130 hours to acquire your game.

That may seem like a lot, but Gamesight also reports that this is only a 17 percent increase over the amount of conversion time needed for free-to-play games, which clocks in at an average of 111 hours. 

Games over $40 face the stiffest challenges when converting players

The literal lower cost of entry makes it a useful baseline for measuring other price points. Games that cost over $40 have an average conversion time of 217 hours, and games priced between $0 and $10 have an average conversion time of 142 hours.

Related:Final Fantasy Tactics - The Ivalice Chronicles sells 1 million units

Games that cost between $10-$20 have an average conversion time of 133 hours—close to the $20-$40 mark. But Gamesight noted that with the average median game price now at about $15.64, this may mean there is "increasing competition from indie games at lower price points." Aiming higher with your game's price could help you stand out from the crowd.

But of course, don't count on your price alone to get people interested in your game. "Channel strategy, not pricing, determines performance," the report notes.

For more insights on how to better market your game—like the impact of improving your Steam user scores and selecting different marketing channels—consider reading the full Gamesight report.
